div.p:
What could be the post town of the Last
Minstrel but Melrose - I think you will like him in his
domestic circle. Lady Scott is most hospitable not only very
civil but really quite kind. Knowing that she is not exactly
the person one would have chosen for Sir Walters wife, people
in general pay her less attention than is due either to her
situation or her talents - She can be very amusing.

When Sir Walter was asked how it had happened that
two such lions as he & Miss Edgeworth had not met when
she was in Edinburgh twenty years ago - he said Oh at that
Time Miss Edgeworth was not the very great Lion she has since become
I for my part my mane had hardly begun to grow". This
was repeated by an intimate friend of his to whom he
said it. He has a wonderful freedom from all vanity he
never seems to be thinking that he is the great unknown. One almost
forgets who is speaking except from the brilliancy of what he says
It was told in Edinburgh that Miss Edgeworth said she did know
she

she had met Sir Walter Scott - & that Sir Walter said he
did know he had met Miss Edgeworth. They were both so perfectly
unpretending.

You will see here a descendant of the noble race
of Pepper & Mustard - the yellow terriers being called Mustard
& the black Pepper, this having a mixture of both is
called Spice - Poor
Dandy Dandie Dinmont is now dead - but he
was so well known to be the original of that character that he was
commonly called Dandy Dandie Dinmont Though not explicitly named, "Dandie Dinmont" refers to James Davidson, the real-life inspiration for Sir Walter Scott's character from Guy Mannering.- a few days before his
death, when he was asked if he was contented to die, . he
answered Oh yes I am ready to leave this world now. I was
favored last Monday with a sight of the hounds in full cry
which I never thought to see again - after such a blessing I
am ready to die content."

Our tour in the Highlands was most prosperous as to
weather & except that Maria was very unwell for some days,
at Fosses we had a delightful tour, as we were four
William sat with Sophy or me, or Sophy & I sat together on
the barouche seats which made an entertaining variety &
allowed of our seeing much more of the country than we
could have done in always sitting in the carriage.-

I do not know how far you mean to go, but there is no
place which is not crowded with recollections either from
what the houds have described or from real history. Near
the Caledonian area - at the eight Lochs called Neptunes Staircase
you are close to Inverlochy Loches (as those books are not here, of
course, I am
not

Abbotsford
Melrose
Maria begs you will thank the Dr. for his note to her
& desires me to tell you that all you need do about
coming here is to write from Edinburgh to fix the day
of your arrival here. For Sir Walter & Lady Scott
enquired inquired
most particularly after Mrs & Miss Brinkley & hoped they
would accompany the Doctor - so that he has only to name
his day & he will be received with open arms.

Maria hopes you will accept the enclosed
note of introduction to some very intimate
friends of ours at Glengore who are as good

& kind as yourselves & will show you all that is best worth
seeing in that busy town.

since as to my spelling/ the castle mentioned in the Legend of
Montrose - you also see though at a distance the Glen where
Chas. Edward first displayed his standard -. On your way
from Fort William, where you see the beginning of the Caledonian
Canal. You might see
Lochiel Locheil wood & dwelling & you must
if you go further than Fort Augustus see the Falls of Foyers -
Near Foyer, where Maria was ill, is the scene of the Witches
conference with Macbeth &c &c.

From Glasgow you can see the Clachan of Aberfoyle
& all Rob Roys country, but I will not bother you with telling
you what you are to see as you will have mu & have much
better advisers - but I think I may venture to say you will not

be disappointed for I think the scenery has far
exceeded any expectations & that there is more
of beauty & of interest than I expected -. We went

to some of the cabins in Lochaber, generally
considered the most dreary part of the Highlands, & they were not as
comfortable as the usual run of Kirk houses - but the people, par
=ticularly particularly the children are much more tidily & better clothed than
in poor Ireland. At Glasgow, all Rob Roy rises before one, but there
is much worth seeing besides. Dr Hooker & his Botanic Gardens
though
not equally beautiful are equally interesting - Mr. Monteiths dying
establishment and the steam worked weaving & tambouring machine
are well worth seeing - I hope you may be there of a Sunday to hear
Dr. Chalmers whom we only happened to meet in society - where he
does not shine. At Edinburgh I think you will like to see the great
reservoir of water which is forming to supply the town & which is not only curious
in itself, but is very near the scenes of the Gentle Shepherd. On the road to
which is
Merchiston Merchistoun Tower where the
Ld. Lord Napier lived. You will find a walk
through the Cowgate & Comongate in "my old romantic town" very well worth
taking & replete with more historic recollections than I have space or
remaining for
Allens Allan's
paintings. & Mr Williams drawings Though it remains unclear to which Allan and Williams the author is referring, there is a strong case for the author referring to David Allan and William Bewick.are the only
